repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This Pull Request changes [Embedding Cython modules in C/C++ applications](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/embedding.html) , adds essential documentation for the new `--embed-modules` feature , which was implemented in #4978 (thanks to @matusvalo) .

**Key content improvements:**

1.  **New Section Added:** Added a new section, "Embedding multiple modules," which documents the usage of the `cython --embed --embed-modules` option and provides a full working example.
2.  **Updating Quick Links:** Updated the "Quick links" section to replace the outdated reference to the `cython_freeze` with the new option `cython --embed-modules` .
3.  **Subtitle Changing:** Renamed the section title from "Embedding example code" to "Embedding a single module" to clearly distinguish it from the new multi-module functionality.
4.  **Change Position of Warning:** Removed the mentions of the `cython_freeze` and consolidated the general warning regarding application portability (external dependencies) from the end of the "Embedding a single module" section into the new "Embedding multiple modules" section.


**Related to:** #4978

comment_data.body: This short example was a little confusing to me just because it seems like part of the `lcmath+combinatorics` example that follows. I think don't use `lcmath` on this line (just to make it clearer that it isn't part of that example)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -69,19 +68,61 @@ The C ``main()`` function of your program could look like this:
 <https://docs.python.org/3/extending/extending.html#the-module-s-method-table-and-initialization-function>`_.)
 
 Instead of writing such a ``main()`` function yourself, you can also let
-Cython generate one into your module's C file with the ``cython --embed``
-option.  Or use the
-`cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_
-script to embed multiple modules.  See the
-`embedding demo program <https://github.com/cython/cython/tree/master/Demos/embed>`_
-for a complete example setup.
-
-Be aware that your application will not contain any external dependencies that
-you use (including Python standard library modules) and so may not be truly portable.
-If you want to generate a portable application we recommend using a specialized
-tool (e.g. `PyInstaller <https://pyinstaller.org/en/stable/>`_
-or `cx_freeze <https://cx-freeze.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html>`_) to find and
-bundle these dependencies.
+Cython generate one into your module's C file with the :option:`cython --embed` option.
+
+
+Embedding multiple modules
+==========================
+
+To statically link multiple Cython modules into a single executable, you must use the
+:option:`cython --embed-modules` option alongside the :option:`cython --embed` option.
+This option enables the necessary C-level initialisation calls (via :c:func:`PyImport_AppendInittab`)
+for all listed modules within the main program's C code.
+
+The argument is a comma-separated list of the module names you wish to embed:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+    cython --embed --embed-modules=lcmath,another_module main_script.pyx

comment_data.body: Thanks for the suggestion, I agree that was confusing. I've updated the line 86 to use generic names (mod1, mod2) and pushed the fix. Please take another look!

 Embedding Cython modules in C/C++ applications
 **********************************************
 
-**This is a stub documentation page. PRs very welcome.**
 
 Quick links:
 
 * `CPython docs <https://docs.python.org/3/extending/embedding.html>`_
 
 * `Cython Wiki <https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/EmbeddingCython>`_
 
-* See the ``--embed`` option to the ``cython`` and ``cythonize`` frontends
-  for generating a C main function and the
-  `cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_
-  script for merging multiple extension modules into one library.
+* See the :option:`cython --embed` option to the ``cython`` and ``cythonize`` frontends

comment_data.body:

```suggestion
  has been superseded by the ``cython --embed-modules`` option.
```

 **********************************************

 Quick links:

-  for generating a C main function and the
-  `cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_
-  script for merging multiple extension modules into one library.
+* See the :option:`cython --embed` option to the ``cython`` and ``cythonize`` frontends
+  for generating a C main function. For embedding multiple modules, the previously used
+  `cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_ script
+  has been superseded by the :option:`cython --embed-modules` option.

comment_data.body:
Here, I would take an opportunity and mention following points points:
1. `embedded.c` and `embedded.h` are generated by cython.
2. `embedded.c` file contains `__Pyx_main()` function which can be adjustd to call  `say_hello_from_python()` - here is snippet of code where added:
    ```c
    gcc -c embedded.c $(python3-config --cflags) -o embedded.o
    gcc embedded.o $(python3-config --ldflags --embed)  -o embedded
    ```
 3. after compilation `embedded` executable is created:
     ```
     $ ./embedded
     Hello from Python!
     ```

comment_data.body:
To produce executable binary you need to add `--embed`:

```suggestion
        gcc lcmath.o combinatorics.o -o combinatorics $(python3-config --ldflags --embed) #link them together statically
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -69,19 +68,61 @@ The C ``main()`` function of your program could look like this:
 <https://docs.python.org/3/extending/extending.html#the-module-s-method-table-and-initialization-function>`_.)
 
 Instead of writing such a ``main()`` function yourself, you can also let
-Cython generate one into your module's C file with the ``cython --embed``
-option.  Or use the
-`cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_
-script to embed multiple modules.  See the
-`embedding demo program <https://github.com/cython/cython/tree/master/Demos/embed>`_
-for a complete example setup.
-
-Be aware that your application will not contain any external dependencies that
-you use (including Python standard library modules) and so may not be truly portable.
-If you want to generate a portable application we recommend using a specialized
-tool (e.g. `PyInstaller <https://pyinstaller.org/en/stable/>`_
-or `cx_freeze <https://cx-freeze.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html>`_) to find and
-bundle these dependencies.
+Cython generate one into your module's C file with the ``cython --embed`` option.
+
+
+Embedding multiple modules
+==========================
+
+To statically link multiple Cython modules into a single executable, you must use the
+``cython --embed-modules`` option alongside the ``cython --embed`` option.
+This option enables the necessary C-level initialisation calls (via :c:func:`PyImport_AppendInittab`)
+for all listed modules within the main program's C code.
+
+The argument is a comma-separated list of the module names you wish to embed:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+    cython --embed --embed-modules=mod1,mod2 main_script.pyx
+
+The full process for static linking, assuming you have ``lcmath.pyx`` and ``combinatorics.pyx``,
+involves these steps:
+
+First, generate the main C code(which includes the ``main()`` function and module initialisers):
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+        cython --embed --embed-modules=lcmath combinatorics.pyx  # creates combinatorics.c
+
+Next, generate the dependency C code:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+        cython lcmath.pyx  # creates lcmath.c
+
+Then, compile the object files:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+        gcc -c combinatorics.c $(python3-config --cflags) -o combinatorics.o # compile combinatorics
+        gcc -c lcmath.c $(python3-config --cflags) -o lcmath.o # compile lcmath
+
+Finally, statically link the executable (linking the object files and the Python library):
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+        gcc lcmath.o combinatorics.o -o combinatorics $(python3-config --ldflags) #link them together statically

comment_data.body:
Here I am missing real content of the file. It is hard to image without it how it works. E.g. I crafted following stupid examples:

lcmath.pyx:

```cython
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

cdef int sub(int a, int b):
    return a - b
```

lcmath.pxd:
```cython
cdef int sub(int a, int b)
```

combinatorics.pyx:
```cython
from lcmath import add
from lcmath cimport sub

cdef public void add_one(int a):
    print(add(a, 1))

cdef public void sub_one(int a):
    print(sub(a, 1))
```

Compilation:
1. `cython  lcmath.pyx`
2. `cython --embed --embed-modules=lcmath combinatorics.pyx`
3. Manual update of `combinatorics.c` - adding `add_one();` and `sub_one();` calls to `__Pyx_main()`
4. `gcc -c combinatorics.c $(python3-config --cflags) -o combinatorics.o`
5. `gcc lcmath.o combinatorics.o $(python3-config --ldflags --embed) -o combinatorics`

After 5th step you should have `combinatorics` binary containing both `lcmath` and `combinatorics` modules.

commit.message: extend documentation to be much explicit

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Doc: Document the new --embed-modules option in tutorials(embedding.rst)
